EDITOR'S NOTE
The first issue published after the Spring Vacation, that
of April 7, included a false front page which contained
April Fool's stories. This issue has laid the News-Letter
open to charges of irresponsible journalism—a fact which
distresses us greatly.
In these stories we attempted to satirize the John Birch
Society, and at the same time, to poke fun at some members
of the faculty and administration. It was our intention that
this would be a harmless and amusing "spoof," and we
a-ssumed it would be taken as such by everyone who read the
paper. The quotes and comments used were all mythical
and completely fabricated; there was no truth at all in any
of the allegations. Especially, there was absolutely no intent
whatsoever to harm anyone or to create any false impressions.
We sincerely regret any embarrassment the stories may
have caused the professors and others who were the targets
of our gibes, and we offer them our earnest and sincere
apologies.

Hickory Dickory Dock
Every time the clock on Gilman Hall ponderously
strikes the hour, or fifteen minute intervals of it, more
and more people suddenly realize that it isn't really striking any more; there are no chimes, no bells, no nothing.
Since the time the Tower was last repaired, the familiar sounds have mysteriously disappeared.
The bells have been a long-standing custom around
here; let's see that they're back very soon, even if they are
five minutes fast.

Non Requiescat In Pace
This issue has been produced in conjunction with
Goucher's Weekly as a sentimental gesture toward the
late-lamented Goucher-Hopkins Coordination Committee.
This group passed out of existence a few weeks ago, its
former duties being assigned to a Student Council committee-man.
The Goucher-Hopkins Coordination idea was one of
those "inspired" plans that started strong but never got
away from the gate. A multitude of areas in which
coordinated activity between these two schools would be
profitable was outlined when student leaders and deans
from Goucher and Hopkins met in November, 1959 to get
activity underway. But of all their noble plans, few were
tried, and none met with any great success.
So the Goucher-Hopkins Committee folded; and this
fine idea faces limbo.
President-elect Bob Abernethy didn't say too .much
about Goucher-Hopkins coordination during his campaign.
We hope this didn't indicate he felt the idea wasn't worth
a new and more vigorous effort to make it succeed. The
News-Letter believes that a successful program of coordinated activities between Goucher and Hopkins would be
immensely worthwhile; and that the failure of this year
should not prevent a second try.

At last we can see Sidney Pratt's plan in progress.
The committees in charge of the letters to President Kennedy and our parents are no longer lists of student names
but functioning groups. .
There, undoubtedly, has been a lag in interest on
campus regarding this project. This could easily have
been predicted, as the time for preparation, organization,
and consolidation necessarily had to be long. Despite the
apparently slow start, steps are being taken toward effecting the proposal and completion is expected in the near
future.
All we can do to overcome this "lag in interest"—
it is unfair to call it "unconcern" or, even worse, "apathy"
—is to remind ourselves that we cannot shirk the responsibility we have undertaken. The success or failure of
this project does not depend upon President Kennedy's
reaction or the parents' response as much as it does upon
the students' efforts and support in meeting this challenge.
It will be a feather in our cap to be able to say "We
planned, we accepted, we completed—and we did the
best that we could." With renewed interest and support,
the "best" should be very fine.

Conference Question
The guests for our Foreign Students' Conference
have all been invited and the schedule of events is almosf
completely outlined. The problem that remains is that of
getting an audience. The solution to this problem—in
fact, the success of the conference as a whole—seems to
hinge upon one question: What is its purpose?
Do the lectures and discussions planned have some
informative, educational purpose or is the conference intended as more of a social function? We strongly suggest
that some statement be made in answer to this question
so that those planning to attend may be properly oriented.

apologies.

Hickory Dickory Dock
Every time the clock on Gilman Hall ponderously
strikes the hour, or fifteen minute intervals of it, more
and more people suddenly realize that it isn't really striking any more; there are no chimes, no bells, no nothing.
Since the time the Tower was last repaired, the familiar sounds have mysteriously disappeared.
The bells have been a long-standing custom around
here; let's see that they're back very soon, even if they are
five minutes fast.

Non Requiescat In Pace
This issue has been produced in conjunction with
Goucher's Weekly as a sentimental gesture toward the
late-lamented Goucher-Hopkins Coordination Committee.
This group passed out of existence a few weeks ago, its
former duties being assigned to a Student Council committee-man.
The Goucher-Hopkins Coordination idea was one of
those "inspired" plans that started strong but never got
away from the gate. A multitude of areas in which
coordinated activity between these two schools would be
profitable was outlined when student leaders and deans
from Goucher and Hopkins met in November, 1959 to get
activity underway. But of all their noble plans, few were
tried, and none met with any great success.
So the Goucher-Hopkins Committee folded; and this
fine idea faces limbo.
President-elect Bob Abernethy didn't say too .much
about Goucher-Hopkins coordination during his campaign.
We hope this didn't indicate he felt the idea wasn't worth
a new and more vigorous effort to make it succeed. The
News-Letter believes that a successful program of coordinated activities between Goucher and Hopkins would be
immensely worthwhile; and that the failure of this year
should not prevent a second try.

At last we can see Sidney Pratt's plan in progress.
The committees in charge of the letters to President Kennedy and our parents are no longer lists of student names
but functioning groups. .
There, undoubtedly, has been a lag in interest on
campus regarding this project. This could easily have
been predicted, as the time for preparation, organization,
and consolidation necessarily had to be long. Despite the
apparently slow start, steps are being taken toward effecting the proposal and completion is expected in the near
future.
All we can do to overcome this "lag in interest"—
it is unfair to call it "unconcern" or, even worse, "apathy"
—is to remind ourselves that we cannot shirk the responsibility we have undertaken. The success or failure of
this project does not depend upon President Kennedy's
reaction or the parents' response as much as it does upon
the students' efforts and support in meeting this challenge.
It will be a feather in our cap to be able to say "We
planned, we accepted, we completed—and we did the
best that we could." With renewed interest and support,
the "best" should be very fine.

Conference Question
The guests for our Foreign Students' Conference
have all been invited and the schedule of events is almosf
completely outlined. The problem that remains is that of
getting an audience. The solution to this problem—in
fact, the success of the conference as a whole—seems to
hinge upon one question: What is its purpose?
Do the lectures and discussions planned have some
informative, educational purpose or is the conference intended as more of a social function? We strongly suggest
that some statement be made in answer to this question
so that those planning to attend may be properly oriented.
